speaker: Wolf Blitzer
date: stated on June 19, 2018 in in an interview:
title: The majority of undocumented migrants appear in court, data shows.
text: The defenders of President Donald Trump ' s aggressive approach to illegal border crossings between the United States and Mexico say that the country faces a dual choice: to hold perpetrators in detention centres while their cases are being decided, or to allow them to be off the radar of immigration authorities. The argument depends on the belief that those released from federal detention without border-crossing documents are more likely to escape the court than to attend mandatory court hearings. This logic led the Trump administration to detain border-crossers in detention facilities without the possibility of bail, in violation of the so-called practice of "fishing and release" in the previous administration. The Acting Director of the Immigration and Customs Department, Thomas Homan, pressed the "no-off" argument in the CNN operating room before the anchor, Wolf Blitzer, retreated. "They'll say the right thing to get released from detention, then they won't appear in court," said Homan June 19. "But they're already in the United States. They're lost in society. They're never removed. So as long as we send this message to the world -- "Come and say the right thing, shoot, never appear in court" -- you will never fix this. Blitzer's response, "most of them appear in court. It doesn't necessarily disappear." The alleged low attendance rate of immigrants to the court has become a popular talking point, from Trump himself ("When we release people, they never return to the judge, however - they have left"), to White House employees and law enforcement officials, to conservative media allies in the administration. In absolute numbers, more than 100,000 migrants who have not been detained in recent years have been ordered to be deported because they have not been brought before an immigration judge. However, as a percentage, most undocumented migrants appear in court. According to the data of the Ministry of Justice from the last available five years, some 60 to 75 per cent of undocumented migrants attended immigration court proceedings. This is determined by subtracting the percentage of sentences handed down against migrants in their absence (known as a judgement in absentia) from the total number of sentences handed down. So Blitzer is right, in percentage terms: most of them appear in court. It should be noted, however, that in absolute terms, approximately 140,000 non-detained migrants ordered their deportation between 2012 and 16 because they were not present in the courtroom, according to Ministry of Justice data. (although some immigration advocates say the count is high.) Peter Margolis, a professor of immigration law and national security law at Roger Williams University Law School, said: "On the issue of the overall importance that immigration officials should attach to non-supply: glass is either half full or half empty," said Peter Margolis, a professor of immigration law and national security law at Roger Williams University Law School. Although the majority attended the hearings, he said, "This continues to give a large number of non-appearances (f) of non-citizens missing." Several experts stressed that the use of monitoring tools and the provision of legal advisers to migrants were linked to high attendance. "I think having adequate legal representation for asylum-seekers would help a lot," said Margolis. "Many may not know that they have good claims. Asylum seekers flee to the United States for fear of persecution in their country because of race, religion or nationality, or because their social or political activities have set a target on their backs. The case of her family is considered to be a "positive" asylum application because the applicants were addressed to the United States authorities to file the application. In contrast, undocumented migrants who apply for asylum during deportation proceedings make a "defence" application. In both cases, migrants must be found to have a credible fear of persecution in order to be considered for asylum. As we have noted before, there has been an increase of approximately 1,700 per cent in American asylum applications over the past 10 years. This increase is fuelled by increased instability, gang violence and deteriorating economic conditions in the "Northern Triangle" countries of Central America, namely, El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras. "At first, much of the male migration was single from Mexico coming to work," said Joshua Presplat, Senior Policy Analyst of the United States Migration Board. "Now you see a transition to Central American families fleeing record levels of violence in the Northern Triangle." So what does the court's attendance rates look like for Ashelus? While data are scarce, they show higher rates, compared with those in which all migrants are grouped together. One of the data sources comes from the Obama Covenant program, which released Assel from detention and matched it with case managers who encouraged compliance with the obligations ordered by the Tribunal. In April, 630 families were registered in the Family Case Management Programme. Before the Trump administration finished the programme in June, participants had a 100 per cent attendance at court sessions. They also had 99 per cent of admissions and appointments with immigration and customs authorities, according to the report of the Office of the Inspector General of the Ministry of Internal Security. "According to the Institute, overall compliance with the programme for all five regions is on average 99 per cent for the Institute's entry and appointment records, as well as 100 per cent of court hearings," the report said. "Since the establishment of FCM, 23 out of 954 participants (2 per cent) have been reported as fugitives." In 2015, the Migration Advocacy Group published a report examining studies over the past two decades and examining the extent to which asylum-seekers have fulfilled their legal obligations. Studies have found "very high compliance rates with procedures by asylum-seekers who have been placed in alternatives to detention." The report cited a study by the United States Government in 2000 which found that "the rate of compliance with court procedures was 83 per cent among asylum-seekers found to have been reliably feared in the accelerated deportation process." It also showed a compliance rate of 84 per cent among migrants under minimum supervision and 78 per cent among those who were not under supervision. A study carried out in 2013 under the auspices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which looked at the Asyles in Toronto and Geneva, indicated a "cooperative readiness" among asylum-seekers. While the study did not specifically look at the islands destined for the United States, it referred to the common characteristics of the islands, including the tendency to "respect the law," perhaps with regard to flight from the original provinces lacking the rule of law. It also noted that asylum-seekers "have no alternative plan" because of "the possibility of repatriation." Our judgment, Blitzer, said, "Most immigrants appear in court." According to data from the Ministry of Justice from the last five years available, some 60-75 per cent of non-detained migrants have attended immigration court proceedings. Some limited data suggest that the rates may be higher for asylum-seekers. However, it is important to note that a large number of migrants have, in absolute terms, issued deportation orders in absentia against them for not appearing in court, which is overlooked in the Blitzer Statement.
